author: By Greg Bensinger
title: Apple’s Illusion of Privacy Is Getting Harder to Sell
description: Our data is as secure as their policies.
content: Even iPhone users with nothing to hide could be forgiven for being a little creeped out that Apple will scan their photos and see if they match existing databases of known illegal pornographic images. Privacy experts called the idea a potential back door for governments to request or demand scans for other images or files. Some of Apple’s own employees are reportedly pushing back on the idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Review: Andrew Lloyd Webber’s Delayed ‘Cinderella’ Is Worth the Wait
description: After months of pandemic-mandated postponements, the British composer’s new show finally had its premiere. It’s fun.
content: LONDON — “Cinderella” finally got there, albeit well past midnight. Five weeks after the show’s aborted July 14 premiere, and with numerous other dates offered and then dropped along the way, Andrew Lloyd Webber’s new musical at last opened here Wednesday at the Gillian Lynne Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Flag Day’ Review: Daddy Dearest
description: Sean Penn directs and stars with his daughter, Dylan Penn, in this intimate yet bumpy family drama.
content: As a director, Sean Penn seems drawn to stories featuring lost children of one sort or another, a proclivity that has resulted in some of his strongest work. His latest film, “Flag Day,” tills similar soil: the awakening of a daughter whose adored father is not the demigod she believes him to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Wildfire smoke has affected air quality in California’s capital.
description: We’re on top of the latest extreme weather in the U.S. and around the world. Follow here for news on heat waves, wildfires, floods and more.
content: The wildfires burning in Northern California, including the rapidly expanding Caldor fire east of Sacramento, are affecting more people than simply those forced to evacuate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Booster shots ‘make a mockery of vaccine equity,’ the W.H.O.’s Africa director says.
description: Coronavirus vaccine doses do more good by giving initial protection to people in low-income countries than by enhancing protection in wealthy nations, said the official, Dr. Matshidiso Moeti.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Africa director at the World Health Organization, Dr. Matshidiso Moeti, criticized the decisions by some wealthy nations to start administering coronavirus booster shots, saying the decisions “make a mockery of vaccine equity” when the African continent is still struggling to get vaccine supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Under the Volcano’ Review: Making Music in Paradise
description: This documentary looks at the recording studio George Martin created in the Caribbean that nurtured the stars of the MTV era.
content: Between this film and “Rockfield: The Studio on the Farm,” there seems to be a minor vogue for documentaries about recording studios this year. The pretext for doing “Under the Volcano” — about the short-lived AIR studio on Montserrat in the Caribbean — is better than solid: The state-of-the-art facility, built by the Beatles producer George Martin, was in the immediate vicinity of the Soufrière Hills volcano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s homes are a four-bedroom in Sea Cliff, N.Y. and a six-bedroom in New Canaan, Conn.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

title: America’s Enduring Arrogance
description: It’s a problem for all presidents, including Biden.
content: This is a preview of the Frank Bruni newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox weekly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: In the ‘Midnight Zone’
description: Oliver Roeder, a longtime member of the puzzle community, makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Well, this has been a long time coming.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens

title: Covid Isn’t Going Away. So What Now?
description: The pandemic will end, eventually. But how soon that happens is anybody’s guess.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: What is Shariah law, and what does it mean for Afghan women?
description: The Taliban have pledged that women will have rights “within the bounds of Islamic law.” What that means depends on who is interpreting it.
content: The Taliban have pledged that women in Afghanistan will have rights “within the bounds of Islamic law,” or Shariah, under their newly established rule. But it is not clear what that will mean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: Anthony Veasna So Made the Debut He’d Always Wanted
description: “Afterparties,” the much-anticipated story collection by the late writer, was a best seller in its first week on sale.
content: A PARTING GIFT Anthony Veasna So, who died of a drug overdose on Dec. 8, never got to see a finished copy of his debut story collection, “Afterparties,” but he’s in every word on the page. Though “it took a village” to carry across the finish line, his editor at Ecco, Helen Atsma, said, “the book is his.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Johnson and Robin Pogrebin
title: Chuck Close, Artist of Outsized Reality, Dies at 81
description: He found success with his large-scale Photorealist portraits, becoming one of the leading artists of his generation. Late in life he faced allegations of sexual harassment.
content: Chuck Close, who rose to prominence in the 1970s and ’80s with colossal Photorealist portraits of himself, family members and fellow artists, but who late in his career faced accusations of sexual harassment, died on Thursday in a hospital in Oceanside, N.Y. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: United Asks Flight Attendants Not to Tape Passengers to Seats
description: Their union called the memo a publicity stunt. But plans by the F.A.A. to fine passengers suggest that the skies remain unruly, as does American Airlines’ extension of its alcohol ban.
content: The bad behavior in America’s skies shows no signs of letting up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Nursing Homes Face Quandary: Vaccinate Staff or Don’t Get Paid.
description: A new policy from President Biden will require all nursing home workers to be vaccinated against Covid. Facilities that fall short could be penalized or lose federal funding.
content: Marita Smith runs a nursing home in Seattle, while Janet Snipes manages one in Denver. They share years of experience in the industry and painful memories of Covid-19, but have sharply differing views of a new federal policy that will mandate vaccinations for all nursing home employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: U.S. Revives Facebook Suit, Adding Details to Back Claim of a Monopoly
description: After a judge slammed the F.T.C.’s original lawsuit, regulators returned with a more detailed case accusing the platform of being a monopoly.
content: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission took new aim at Facebook on Thursday, beefing up its accusations that the company was a monopoly that illegally crushed competition, in an attempt to overcome the skepticism of a federal judge who threw out the agency’s original case two months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Peter Rehberg, a Force in Underground Music, Dies at 53
description: He released his own experiments with sound under the name Pita, and also ran the influential label Editions Mego.
content: It was 1997, and Peter Rehberg and two collaborators had booked a tour of jazz and rock clubs, places that had probably seen their share of experimentation. The people who came to the shows, though, weren’t prepared for what the trio unveiled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Marc Santora and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Taliban Quash Protests and Seize Enemies, Tightening Grip on Afghanistan
description: The Taliban’s actions and history of brutality cast doubt on their promises of amnesty, and many Afghans are afraid to venture out of their homes.
content: The Taliban cracked down on protests that erupted in at least four cities in Afghanistan on Thursday and rounded up opponents despite promises of amnesty, even as fearful workers stayed home and thousands of people continued a frenzied rush to leave the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Annie Karni and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Sluggish Visa Process Strands Thousands of Afghans Who Worked for U.S.
description: Officials described impatience across the Biden administration with the State Department as thousands of Afghans wait outside Kabul’s airport.
content: WASHINGTON — A sluggish State Department response to the Taliban’s rapid takeover of Kabul, Afghanistan’s capital, has stranded thousands of Afghans who helped the United States and are now clamoring to be evacuated as they wait for their immigration visas to be approved, two U.S. officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
title: China’s Biggest ‘Bad Bank’ Will Get a Rescue
description: After months of silence about its future, the corporate giant Huarong Asset Management announced that it would receive financial assistance from a group of state-backed companies.
content: China has promised to teach its most indebted companies a lesson. Just not yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Hypebeasts Hit the Road
description: Forget the factory model. For certain status chasers, the Abushi brothers take car customization to the next level — with luxury price tags to match.
content: It is, by its owner’s description, a “zombie killer” dream machine — a 2021 Mercedes-Benz SUV G-Wagon/Brabus, Frankenstein-built using organs from a sacrificial donor auto, custom portal axles, 16-inch lifts that elevate the roofline to Manute Bol height, tires so pneumatic that custom bumpers and fenders were machined to give them clearance, a roof rack resembling the launchpad for a drone fleet and two-toned honeybee-colored interiors as detailed as a Dutch still life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Protégé’ Review: Ladykiller
description: Maggie Q and Michael Keaton play characters that get turned on by termination in this monumentally silly action movie.
content: “The Protégé,” — a lady-assassin movie whose heroine is as indestructible as the genre clichés surrounding her — might profit from the unexpected presence of Michael Keaton, but not by much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: How the Pandemic Changed Abortion Access
description: During the pandemic, health care providers can send abortion medication by mail. Will the courts allow that to continue?
content: The challenges of the pandemic have resulted in new ways of providing care that reach beyond Covid-19 treatments and vaccines. One area of medicine that could see changes is abortion care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Is Shohei Ohtani ‘the New Babe Ruth,’ or Something Entirely New?
description: The two-way star for the Los Angeles Angels draws countless comparisons to the Yankees legend, but their paths are fairly different.
content: “The 21st century Babe Ruth.” “The modern-day Babe Ruth.” “The greatest two-way player since Babe Ruth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Paw Patrol: The Movie’ Review: Young Dogs, Old Tricks
description: In their first big-screen outing, the frisky rescue pups of the popular animated series “Paw Patrol” stay forever young.
content: While many franchises aimed at children smuggle in some adult-appeal added-value — you know! for parents! — “Paw Patrol” is not one of them. The adventures of the squad of anthropomorphized rescue puppies, set in the environs of Adventure Bay, are entirely toddler-friendly and irony-free.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Mysteries can help a plot gallop along even when the book you’re reading isn’t strictly speaking a “mystery,” plucked from the crime shelves of your local library. That’s certainly the case for three of the novels on this week’s list: In one, an immigrant searches for her missing husband, in another the return of a prodigal daughter brings buried family secrets to light, and in the third a hard-boiled Sam Spade-ish cryptozoologist stalks mystical creatures through the streets of a Chinese city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Maria Cramer
title: Man Surrenders to Capitol Police After ‘Bomb Threat’ Near Library of Congress
description: The police closed off several streets and sent alerts to congressional staff members, prompting evacuations.
content: WASHINGTON — A man who claimed to have a bomb in a pickup outside the Library of Congress surrendered to the police on Thursday, after hours of negotiations and evacuations of several government buildings in the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: When a Stranger Knocks at the Airlock
description: Edward Einhorn’s “Alma Baya” is the bleak, humor-flecked tale of two clones on a distant planet who let a third inside their walls.
content: Inside their white-walled home on the surface of a hostile planet, Alma and Baya have only each other for company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Recalled Pet Food May Be Linked to 130 Dog Deaths, F.D.A. Says
description: The agency warned Midwestern Pet Foods Inc. that its dry dog food may also have sickened 220 pets.
content: The Food and Drug Administration has warned a pet food manufacturer that its dry dog food may be linked to the deaths of 130 dogs and that its products may have sickened an additional 220 pets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Three People I Would Interview About Afghanistan
description: Imagining conversations on Afghanistan.
content: As I watch events in Afghanistan unfold, I find myself trying to ignore all the commentary and longing instead to interview three people: President Lyndon Johnson, Chinese President Xi Jinping and Mohammed Zahir Shah, the last king of Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: Children with disabilities sue the Texas governor over his ban on school mask mandates.
description: The suit in federal court, which argues that the ban denies medically at-risk children equal access to a safe education, could set a national precedent.
content: Parents of young children with disabilities are suing Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas over his ban on mask mandates in public schools, arguing that the executive order, signed in July, prevents their medically at-risk children from being able to attend school safely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: When Theater Installations Aim to Make Room for Drama
description: These worthy and adventurous lockdown experiments too often give short shrift to the relationship between a script and how an audience takes it in.
content: For the last year and a half, I’ve imagined shuttered theaters as shrines to live performance — the empty seats, the leftover sets, the lone ghost lights lit like memorial candles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Demonic’ Review: Making a Hash of a Genre Mash-Up
description: In his latest, the director Neill Blomkamp plays around with different genre elements but never figures out how to make them cohere.
content: Flat acting, risible dialogue, a witless story — sometimes when a movie hits this trifecta so completely, it engenders a feeling of disreputable pleasure. It’s bad, and you know it, and maybe the filmmakers know it too. How could they not? Yet somehow all the suboptimal (inept, incoherent) elements mysteriously cohere into a work that finds its own perverse groove. “Demonic” is not such a singular amusement. It’s just a drag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: When the Fires Came, the Store Went Online
description: An outdoor gear store is a test of what it’s like to start an e-commerce site in 2021.
content: This is a preview of the On Tech With Shira Ovide newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox three times a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: A 17-year-old Afghan soccer player died falling from a U.S. evacuation plane.
description: Frantic to flee the Taliban, he joined a desperate crush at the Kabul airport. “He had no hope and wanted a better life,” a sports official said.
content: A member of Afghanistan’s national youth soccer team was among the people who were killed as they tried desperately to cling to a U.S. military plane evacuating people from Kabul this week, the country’s official sports federation said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: The U.S. wants a U.N. meeting scaled back to avoid a ‘superspreader event.’
description: The annual General Assembly meeting would ordinarily attract scores of heads of state and other top officials to New York. But American officials say it should be mainly virtual again this year for safety’s sake.
content: The United States has requested that the United Nations scale back the annual General Assembly meeting in New York next month, making it a mostly virtual gathering, to avoid the “superspreader” infection risks posed by the pandemic’s highly contagious Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Judge John Hodgman on Dads Doing Dad Things
description: A father exerts his right to embarrass his son.
content: Jason writes: My son and I went to see the famous mentalist the Amazing Kreskin. Part of Kreskin’s act was pretending to be in constant danger of falling down. After the show, I pulled a comedic pratfall of my own. But my son thought I actually fell and has never stopped talking about it. Please order him to stop saying this. I also seek damages in the form of a Tom Collins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Explains How ‘Forever Wars’ Happen
description: The Washington elite kept troops in Afghanistan “longer than it takes for George R.R. Martin to come up with a new ‘Game of Thrones’ book,” Meyers joked.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Some Assembly Required
description: An expertly curated platter makes for ideal late-summer eating.
content: One of my favorite things to do on my birthday is to throw my own dinner party (yep, I’m a Leo). A grand aioli is always a strong contender in late August, and Kay Chun’s is calling to me with its bright green aioli, packed with herbs, which you can easily make vegan — notes on that below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: 20 Wines Under $20: For When the Weather Is Sultry
description: The needs are different when it’s hot and sticky: Lighter-bodied wines, more whites and rosés than reds, refreshment rather than solidity.
content: Few things influence the choice of wine as much as the weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Nursing homes will have to vaccinate staff to get federal funds.
content: On Wednesday, President Biden said that all nursing home employees must be vaccinated by Sept. 30. Any facilities that don’t comply will not receive federal Medicare or Medicaid funds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Emily Palmer
title: R. Kelly Knowingly Infected Accusers With Herpes, They Say
description: Over the first two days of the singer’s trial, Jerhonda Pace testified that Mr. Kelly told her to dress like a girl scout and gave her an S.T.D. at age 16.
content: R. Kelly’s longtime Chicago doctor revealed on Thursday that the R&B singer was being treated for herpes in 2007 — more than two years before one of his accusers testified that he had passed the disease to her without warning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Annie Karni
title: The U.S. and other nations step up evacuation flights.
description: Crowds continued to camp out near Kabul’s airport on Thursday, while U.S. troops tried to quell the chaos and accelerate the evacuation flights.
content: Crowds continued to camp out near Kabul’s airport on Thursday, while U.S. troops tried to quell the chaos and accelerate the evacuation flights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: New Crime Novels from Louise Penny and Silvia Moreno-Garcia
description: End-of-summer whodunits bring chills and thrills.
content: Crime novels incorporating the pandemic into their plots are starting to appear. The verdicts vary, but I admired Louise Penny’s approach in her 17th Inspector Gamache novel, THE MADNESS OF CROWDS (Minotaur, 448 pp., $28.99): She sets the action in the aftermath, with vaccines in plentiful supply and society opening up. “There was loss, but vivid new life had also emerged from the ash,” Gamache thinks, feeling a wave of relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Seeking Global Recognition, Taliban Take a New Approach: Making Nice
description: The group’s head-spinning claims of moderation follow a common playbook for rebel-held governments, with mixed lessons for Afghanistan’s future.
content: The Taliban may occupy Afghanistan’s border crossings and government offices, but what they control falls far short of a fully functioning country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greta Thunberg, Adriana Calderón, Farzana Faruk Jhumu and Eric Njuguna
title: Three Years After Greta Thunberg’s Strike, Adults Are Failing Children on a Global Scale
description: 'We will not allow the world to look away.'
content: Last week, some of the world’s leading climate change scientists confirmed that humans are making irreversible changes to our planet and extreme weather will only become more severe. This news is a “code red for humanity,” said the United Nations secretary general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Are You Ready for Sentient Disney Robots?
description: Some of the animatronics at Disney’s parks have been doing their herky-jerky thing since the Nixon administration. The company knows that nostalgia won’t cut it with today’s children.
content: GLENDALE, Calif. — I was en route to meet Groot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Some Bat Pups Babble Just Like Human Babies
description: Pups of one bat species show a remarkable similarity to infants of our own species in the way they emit complex streams of syllables.
content: Great sac-winged bats are a field biologist’s dream. They hunt insects at dawn and dusk, stay awake much of the day and rest at night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: City workers in Los Angeles will soon have to get vaccinated.
description: The vaccine mandate in Los Angeles reflects a broader trend toward harsher measures, from the White House down, to push the Americans who are still not vaccinated to get the shots as the Delta variant ravages the United States.
content: The Los Angeles City Council passed on Wednesday a Covid-19 vaccine mandate for nearly 60,000 city workers, including police officers and firefighters, that did not include an option for regular testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carly Stern
title: ‘Grandfamily’ Housing Caters to Older Americans Raising Children
description: Intergenerational communities are sprouting up as the need grows for homes that suit aging adults and their young charges.
content: When Jackie Lynn’s niece gave birth to a baby who was addicted to heroin, Ms. Lynn sprang into action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Snyder and Pia Riverola
title: A French Designer Who Celebrates Mexico’s Popular-Design Aesthetic
description: In his colorful Guadalajara work space, Fabien Cappello collects and creates pieces he calls “prototypes of the future.”
content: EVERY AFTERNOON, YOLANDA González Murillo passes by the open front door of the French industrial designer Fabien Cappello’s studio in the Mexican city of Guadalajara selling icy paletas that she pulls from frost-slicked molds. The flavors change with the seasons: walnut and vanilla in the winter, mango in the spring and prickly pear in the summer, all made from produce that González purchases from a market in the working-class neighborhood of Alcalde Barranquitas. The ice pops are delicious, Cappello says, but he’s more drawn to their molds: long, tapered wands of stainless steel made for decades by a family of metalworkers in the lakeside town of Chapala, an hour away.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Crime Novelist William Kent Krueger Still Loves Sherlock Holmes
description: “Is there a more mysterious and nefarious villain than Moriarty?”
content: “Is there a more mysterious and nefarious villain than Moriarty?” asks the mystery writer William Kent Krueger, whose latest Cork O’Connor book is “Lightning Strike.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Texas Can Ban Common Form of Second-Trimester Abortion, Appeals Court Rules
description: The lower court “committed numerous, reversible legal and factual errors,” according to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
content: A federal appeals court on Wednesday upheld a Texas law banning the most common form of second-trimester abortion, ruling that a lower court had erred in finding that the law imposed “an undue burden on a large fraction of women.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Court Blocks a Vast Alaskan Drilling Project, Citing Climate Dangers
description: The multibillion-dollar ConocoPhillips plan, known as Willow, was approved under the Trump administration and then legally supported by the Biden administration.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge in Alaska on Wednesday blocked construction permits for an expansive oil drilling project on the state’s North Slope that was designed to produce more than 100,000 barrels of oil a day for the next 30 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Night House’ Review: Mourning Becomes Her
description: A sensational Rebecca Hall plays a grieving widow besieged by potentially occult forces in this superior creepout.
content: The scares land like blows and the eeriness is pervasive in “The Night House,” David Bruckner’s hyper-focused, unnervingly sure follow-up to his 2018 wilderness frightener, “The Ritual.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Western Drought Will Last Into Fall or Longer
description: The forecast, from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, comes as almost half of the land area of the lower 48 states is experiencing drought.
content: The severe drought that has gripped much of the western half of the United States in spring and summer is likely to continue at least into late fall, government forecasters said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Historical Guide to Renaming the Washington Football Team
description: N.F.L. team names have followed trends in certain eras, a practice that could give the Washington franchise more options for its rebranding.
content: The Washington Football Team ignited renewed speculation about its future nickname this week by releasing a video about its rebranding that cited eight possible names. While Jason Wright, the team’s president, eventually said other candidates were also being considered, that didn’t stop every fan within 3,000 miles of the capital from weighing in on the pros and cons of each suggestion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Those plastic barriers probably don’t help and may even make things worse.
description: Covid precautions have turned many parts of our world into a giant salad bar, with plastic barriers separating sales clerks from shoppers, dividing customers at nail salons and shielding students from their classmates.
content: Covid precautions have turned many parts of our world into a giant salad bar, with plastic barriers separating sales clerks from shoppers, dividing customers at nail salons and shielding students from their classmates.

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: Through the years, Rockaway Beach has earned the distinction of being a site synonymous with resilience. Knowing that, Ivan Forde recently painted “Seascape With the Fabulous Plant of Rejuvenation in the Abzu,” an 18-foot-by-90-foot mural at the corner of Rockaway Beach Boulevard and Beach 108th Street on the facade of Rockaway Hotel. The work symbolizes “rejuvenation for N.Y.C. after the storm of the pandemic,” he said in a personal statement on his website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Joe Galloway, Decorated Vietnam War Correspondent, Dies at 79
description: He chronicled the first major battle of the war in “We Were Soldiers Once … and Young” and raised questions about the invasion of Iraq.
content: Joe Galloway, a war correspondent whose wrenching account of the first major battle of the Vietnam War was the basis for the book “We Were Soldiers Once … and Young,” which became a best seller and the basis of a hit movie, died on Wednesday in Concord, N.C. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Is Jeremy O. Harris’s Play for ‘Gossip Girl’ Real? Now It Is.
description: Joshua Safran’s “Gossip Girl” reboot filmed a scene from an imaginary work by the “Slave Play” playwright. Then the Public Theater commissioned it.
content: We hear him before we see him come across the screen: Aaron howls and barks then gallops, on all fours, onto a white, wooden thrust stage, ringed on three sides by the audience. This enraged man — the son of Aaron the Moor from “Titus Andronicus” — is stark naked and covered in blood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Anton Troianovski
title: With Afghan Collapse, Moscow Takes Charge in Central Asia
description: Along with Pakistan and China, Russia has gained broad influence in security matters at the expense of the United States and India.
content: DUSHANBE, Tajikistan — As the Afghan government collapsed this week in Kabul and the United States scrambled to speed up its evacuation effort, hundreds of Russian armored vehicles and artillery pieces were clearly visible hundreds of miles away, on the border with Tajikistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our critic recommends a rom-com, a sad-com and a wild new sports documentary.
content: This is a preview of the Watching newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox four times a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Scottish Soccer’s Brexit Problem: No Way In, and No Way Out
description: Boxed in by stricter rules for imported players and rising prices for British ones, Scotland’s clubs may struggle to stay competitive.
content: Juhani Ojala knew he would have to wait. Travel restrictions were still in place in Scotland when, in the middle of July, the Finnish defender agreed to join Motherwell, a club of modest means and sober ambitions in the country’s top division. Upon landing, Ojala knew, he would have to spend 10 days isolating in a hotel before joining his new teammates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Online Appeal Quickly Raises Millions for Afghan Rescue Flights
description: Some refugee experts were skeptical about a GoFundMe campaign by an Instagram personality working with veterans and other groups.
content: An online appeal for donations to organize flights to rescue vulnerable Afghans from the Taliban has quickly found a large audience of Americans eager to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Want to Solve the Housing Crisis? Take Over Hotels.
description: A discussion on the escalating problem of unaffordability.
content: This is a preview of the Jay Caspian Kang newsletter, which is reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox twice a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Osmon
title: 54 Albums Later, Connie Smith’s Defiant Heart Has Plenty to Say
description: The country artist, 80, is releasing her first secular recording in about a decade. Her husband, Marty Stuart, calls her “the ultimate outlaw” for doing things her way.
content: What’s the meaning of country music?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Tepperman
title: America’s Uncertain Role in the World After 9/11
description: Spencer Ackerman’s “Reign of Terror” explores how the attacks of 9/11 have influenced American policy over the last 20 years — and not in a good way.
content: REIGN OF TERRORHow the 9/11 Era Destabilized America and Produced TrumpBy Spencer Ackerman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Last Man Standing’ Review: Revisiting a Murder (and a Murder Doc)
description: The British documentarian Nick Broomfield tries, again, to solve the killing of Biggie Smalls.
content: In “Last Man Standing,” subtitled “Suge Knight and the Murders of Biggie & Tupac,” the British documentarian Nick Broomfield tries to tie up loose ends from his “Biggie and Tupac” (2002). That movie presented an unproven conspiracy theory that the rap mogul Marion Knight, widely known as Suge, was involved, along with corrupt police officers, in the 1997 shooting death of Christopher Wallace, a.k.a. Biggie Smalls, in Los Angeles, and the 1996 killing of Tupac Shakur in Las Vegas. (Broomfield appears to tacitly roll back that claim in the new film, which gives a different emphasis to the events surrounding Shakur’s death.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Chaotic scenes in Afghanistan.
content: President Biden’s decision not to begin a mass evacuation from Afghanistan of interpreters, guides and their relatives earlier has left thousands in limbo. Women in particular are frantically erasing their links to the U.S. for fear that they will be targeted by the Taliban. The U.S. evacuated 2,000 people, mostly Afghans and NATO personnel, from Kabul in 24 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: For Mets Offense, ‘the Message Was Sent, and We Got It’
description: The free-swinging team had been in free-fall when Steven Cohen snapped, criticizing the offense. An extra-innings win on Wednesday turned the volume down.
content: The Mets held a four-game lead in the National League East on the morning of Aug. 1. They woke up on Wednesday in third place, four and a half games behind the Atlanta Braves. They also awoke to a blustery tweet from their owner, Steve Cohen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Firshein
title: Help! What Will I Need to Show When Traveling, and Where?
description: Proof of vaccination has become increasingly vital to accessing local restaurants and distant countries alike. Our columnist takes a deeper dive into what that means for travelers.
content: I am writing with a simple question: What is an acceptable proof of vaccination for U.S. travelers? I have the C.D.C. card, but that’s just a piece of paper that anybody can easily recreate, and its authenticity cannot be verified in the same way as a passport or driver’s license. What if I am given this argument at the airport check-in counter? George
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: The Dos and Don’ts of Fermented Foods
description: Is all yogurt created equal? Does it matter if the kimchi is spicy? And what if my kombucha has sugar? Your questions answered.
content: This is a preview of the Well newsletter, which is reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox weekly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass, Patricia Heal and Linda Heiss
title: The Ceramists Crafting Miniature Menageries
description: Inspired by ancient animal figurines, contemporary potters are making creatures that reflect the irregular beauty and magic of the natural world.
content: ARTISTS HAVE MADE animals from clay for nearly as long as history has been recorded. Among the artifacts unearthed at the legendary 1983 archaeological dig in Jordan’s Ain Ghazal were a number of small creatures from the Neolithic period, some of the earliest objects of their kind ever found. At first, archaeologists wondered if the reddish, palm-size bulls they discovered had been children’s toys, but they soon realized that their function was largely spiritual — magical, even: They were totems at the site’s temple altar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: How This Texas Town Became One of America’s Fastest-Growing Cities
description: Known for its German roots and its world-famous water park, New Braunfels, Texas, in the thriving corridor between San Antonio and Austin, grew 56 percent over the past decade.
content: ﻿NEW BRAUNFELS, Texas — In the not-too-distant past, motorists driving along a stretch of Interstate 35 just northeast of San Antonio were met with vast fields of wildflowers and grazing cows in grassy pastures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Deal Provides Aid to Gazans, but Reconstruction Is Elusive
description: Millions will be funneled to impoverished families under an agreement reached by the United Nations and Qatar, a step forward in firming up a cease-fire with Israel.
content: JERUSALEM — Millions in aid will be funneled to impoverished families in the blockaded Gaza Strip under a deal reached by the United Nations and Qatar on Thursday, marking a significant advance in efforts to firm up a cease-fire between Israel and the militant group Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: I Hit the Neighbors’ Dog With My Car. What Now?
description: A young reader asks for advice on confessing.
content: I am staying with my parents until I go back to college in September. A few days ago, while I was driving home — way below the speed limit! — the neighbors’ dog darted into the street. (It looked like he was chasing something.) I slammed on my brakes and felt a thud. I got out of the car and saw that I had hit the dog. He was dead. I carried him to my neighbors’ house, but no one was home. So, I left him on the doorstep. I was going to write a note, but I chickened out. Now, the neighbors have posted signs around the neighborhood asking if anyone knows what happened. I feel terrible! Is it too late to speak up?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: How Jason Miller Is Trying to Get Trump Back on the Internet
description: And, potentially, back in the White House.
content: Social media has felt quieter without the constant ALL CAPS fury of Donald Trump, but Jason Miller is trying to change that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Out of Storage and Onto Walls, the Uffizi Spreads Its Brand
description: The gallery in Florence is lending artworks from its depots to smaller towns throughout Tuscany, increasing their appeal and strengthening its ties to the region.
content: CASTAGNO D’ANDREA, Italy — This tiny hamlet with a population of around 300, located 40 winding miles northeast of Florence, has never been on Italy’s must-see A-list. Its main claim to fame is that it was the birthplace of the Renaissance painter Andrea del Castagno, who left as a child, most likely before he was old enough to doodle on the local walls. (If he did, there are no remnants of his scrawls.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Stenquist
title: The Dream Cars of the Car Designers
description: Saturday mornings are for celebrating stylish sheet metal in the parking lot of a storied hobby shop in metro Detroit.
content: DETROIT — What do the men and women who design cars drive? What kind of machines do sheet-metal artists park in their garages? A recent Saturday morning at Pasteiner’s Auto Zone Hobbies on Woodward Avenue in metro Detroit provided some interesting answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Reminiscence’ Review: Out of the Past, Into the Future (and Back)
description: In her feature debut, the co-creator of HBO’s “Westworld” toys with time, space, clichés and conventions in a narrative hall of mirrors.
content: Highfalutin, lightly enjoyable mush, “Reminiscence” is one of those speculative fictions that are at once undernourished and overcooked. It makes no sense (despite all the explaining), but it draws you in with genre beats, pretty people and the professional polish of its machined parts. It’s shiny and pricey and looks good on the big screen; it is also the newest addition to what now plays like the Nolan Family Extended Universe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Cryptozoo’ Review: Wild Things
description: This animated film is a rapturously hallucinogenic daydream for mature audiences.
content: In one of the year’s most memorable openers, Matthew and Amber, a hippyish couple voiced by Michael Cera and Louisa Krause, make love under the stars, their naked, fleshy bodies enveloped by the blank, black space that is the forest around them. It’s an eerily enchanting scene flecked with droll humor that gives way to industrial menace when the duo stumble upon a towering chain link fence hiding something both wonderful and terrible: a whole wide world of unicorns, griffins, hydras — you name it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Ellin
title: Brazilian Butt Lifts Surge, Despite Risks
description: The procedure has the highest mortality rate of any cosmetic surgery, but many women are undaunted.
content: The perfect body, in Diana Dayyani’s estimation, belongs to a cartoon character. Not just any animated character, not Wilma Flintstone or Betty Rubble, but a rabbit. Jessica Rabbit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsea Garrison, Annie Brown, Stella Tan, Luke Vander Ploeg, Neena Pathak, Rob Szypko, M.J. Davis Lin, Larissa Anderson, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Interpreters the U.S. Left Behind in Afghanistan
description: We speak to several Afghans who aided the Americans and to their former U.S. colleagues trying to get them out.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: A Quirky Design Fair Finds a New Home: Governors Island
description: The Inventgenuity Festival, which runs this weekend, invites young participants to complete a public-art project, among other creative activities.
content: Most art and design fairs geared toward young people encourage them to create something to take home. The Inventgenuity Festival does that, too, but it emphasizes a rarer and possibly more resonant principle: creating something to leave behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: A Starter Kit for Biking in New York
description: A few tips if you’re new to urban biking — or if you’re rediscovering it.
content: With gyms closed (and now reopened with restrictions) and some wary of public transportation, many New Yorkers have embraced biking for commuting and recreation during the pandemic. While increased demand and a disruption of the supply chain has created a shortage of bikes, there is plenty of good news: cycling is good for the health of both the biker and the environment, and it makes for an overall more livable city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meryl Cates
title: Oklahoma’s Gift to Ballet: The Five Moons Ballerinas
description: A festival at the University of Oklahoma celebrates the impact of these ballerinas on 20th century ballet, honoring their Native American heritage.
content: At the first Oklahoma Indian Ballerina Festival, in 1957, its founder, Moscelyne Larkin, danced Myrtha in Act Two of “Giselle” and Maria Tallchief performed an excerpt from “Swan Lake.” It was a festival created to honor five Native American ballerinas, all hailing from Oklahoma. But it would take 10 years, and the premiere of a ballet, “The Four Moons,” for the festival to really celebrate the dancers’ heritages as well as their artistry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Dudding
title: Afghanistan, Vaccines, Chuck Close: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kazin
title: To Save His Presidency, Biden Must Tell the Truth About Afghanistan
description: He may not be able to save his ambitious legislative agenda unless he understands this crucial lesson from the past.
content: For days now, the news media has likened the chaotic end of our misadventure in Afghanistan, and the awful images of terrified people scrambling onto planes at the Kabul airport, to the final exit from South Vietnam. The comparison is overdrawn; the last American combat troops left Indochina two years before the collapse of the Saigon government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: Why Some People in Chinatown Oppose a Museum Dedicated to Their Culture
description: In Manhattan’s Chinatown, anti-gentrification protesters are furious over funding granted to a museum that they say doesn’t represent their community.
content: Twice a week, Li Zhen Tan, a former dim sum server, plants herself in front of the Museum of Chinese in America in Chinatown and joins the fervent chants of dozens of others like her who have congregated there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: The ZIP Codes to Watch in Real Estate
description: A recent study compares postal zones, ranking those with the most in-demand listings and the fastest-selling homes.
content: During the pandemic, home prices in cities and towns across the country have been rising. But what does that trend look like if you dig down to the ZIP code level to get a granular view of where the action is? Realtor.com did just that in its annual report on the hottest ZIP codes in U.S. real estate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: An Afghan Journey From Kabul to the Bay Area
description: A former interpreter for the U.S. military moved from Kabul to Martinez last week. He longs for the family that he left behind.
content: MARTINEZ — Ahmed Azizi, a former interpreter for U.S. Special Forces in Afghanistan, is living between two worlds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Three vaccinated senators have tested positive for the virus.
description: Roger Wicker, Republican of Mississippi, Angus King, independent of Maine, and John Hickenlooper, Democrat of Colorado, said on Tuesday that they were experiencing symptoms.
content: Senators Roger Wicker, Republican of Mississippi, Angus King, independent of Maine, and John Hickenlooper, Democrat of Colorado, said on Thursday that they had tested positive for the coronavirus, adding to the number of breakthrough cases among lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Quiet Rage of the Responsible
description: It's time to stop being diffident and speak up.
content: Let’s talk for a minute about Lollapalooza. After canceling in-person events last year, a few weeks ago Chicago once again hosted the long-running music festival, drawing more than 385,000 people. Many feared that the huge, raucous crowds could produce a coronavirus superspreader event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Many rebels before the Taliban also promised moderation after seizing power.
description: The Taliban may occupy Afghanistan’s border crossings and government offices, but what they control falls far short of a fully functioning country. Services like water, electricity and trash pickup are faltering as state employees hide out at home. The central bank sits effectively empty, with Washington having frozen Afghan government reserves held in U.S. bank accounts.
content: The Taliban may occupy Afghanistan’s border crossings and government offices, but what they control falls far short of a fully functioning country. Services like water, electricity and trash pickup are faltering as state employees hide out at home. The central bank sits effectively empty, with Washington having frozen Afghan government reserves held in U.S. bank accounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Wildland’ Review: Loyalty Makes You Family
description: A teenage girl is roped into her estranged aunt’s criminal activities in this psychodrama by the Danish filmmaker Jeanette Nordahl.
content: In “Wildland,” by the Danish filmmaker Jeanette Nordahl, the 17-year-old Ida (Sandra Guldberg Kampp) is roped into her mysterious aunt Bodil’s family business after a car accident kills Ida’s mother. Still in mourning, our soft-spoken yet observant protagonist is eased into the family circle, coming-of-age, so to speak, as the violent reality of their criminal affairs come into view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Those Anti-Covid Plastic Barriers Probably Don’t Help and May Make Things Worse
description: Clear barriers have sprung up at restaurants, nail salons and school classrooms, but most of the time, they do little to stop the spread of the coronavirus.
content: Covid precautions have turned many parts of our world into a giant salad bar, with plastic barriers separating sales clerks from shoppers, dividing customers at nail salons and shielding students from their classmates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: California’s wildfires prompt a surge in evacuations.
description: We’re on top of the latest extreme weather in the U.S. and around the world. Follow here for news on heat waves, wildfires, floods and more.
content: For weeks the wildfires in Northern California — which have so far burned more than 1.3 million acres of land — have mostly skipped across sparsely populated areas and have not required mass evacuations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sealey and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: medical history
description: This is one of those poems that turn a list into something more: a moral of the awe and desperation of the world.
content: I’ve always believed that the poet writing in the first person is the best fabulist, that most peculiar of words that means both “composer of fables” and “inventory of elaborate lies.” Nicole Sealey’s “medical history” is one of those poems that turn a list into something more: a moral of the awe and desperation of the world. The North Star and all the rest might be long dead, just as the details of our lives might just be the past — and yet, sometimes the past leads us to freedom, and there is beauty in the remembering and noticing of it all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabine Hossenfelder
title: The Miracle Cure for All Our Energy Woes?
description: In “The Star Builders,” Arthur Turrell explores the attempt to produce clean and abundant energy through nuclear fusion.
content: THE STAR BUILDERSNuclear Fusion and the Race to Power the PlanetBy Arthur Turrell
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘The Smartest Kids in the World’ Review: Putting School to the Test
description: This documentary aspires to offer a study of education worldwide, but it lacks in economic and cultural context.
content: As summer ends and families agonize over how to send children back to school safely, we receive an education documentary that was plainly produced before the pandemic. “The Smartest Kids in the World” aspires to offer a study of teaching methods worldwide, but the documentary (on Discovery+) contains little rigor. It’s a dippy lecture in motion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Ben Decker
title: The Taliban’s use of social media is a thorny problem for tech companies.
description: As the Taliban took control of Kabul, a spokesman for the group uploaded five videos to his official YouTube page. The videos, each two to three minutes long, showed Taliban leaders congratulating fighters on their victories.
content: As the Taliban took control of Kabul, a spokesman for the group uploaded five videos to his official YouTube page. The videos, each two to three minutes long, showed Taliban leaders congratulating fighters on their victories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanif  Abdurraqib
title: Saving Pop Punk? That’s Just Their Warm-Up Act.
description: Meet Me @ the Altar want to be household names — and that’s not a crazy notion.
content: Depending on where you’re from and where you’ve been, you may be able to imagine a place like Davenport, Fla., which vibrates with the sleepy malaise of suburban sameness. Beige strip-mall storefronts unfurl along the streets. Some have no real names, just signs reading BARBER, TATTOOS, GUNS, TACOS. Davenport is about 35 miles from the center of Orlando, and on the drive the freeway starts to loosen and flow more easily. The atmosphere quiets. The signs of chain restaurants push into the dimming sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: The Moral Philosopher of YouTube
description: Dhar Mann has built an online video empire on contemporary fables.
content: The internet is not exactly a repository of moral guidance. Yet over the past few years, millions of viewers have flocked to the YouTube channel Dhar Mann to watch contemporary fables. Instead of talking animals, these videos feature stock characters learning lessons in a format tailored to the uncanny algorithmic currents of social media. It’s Aesop meets Upworthy, by way of Logan Paul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: A Quiet Summer at Edinburgh’s Festivals
description: There are fewer shows and smaller audiences than usual at the International Festival and the Fringe this year.
content: EDINBURGH — Quiet isn’t a word usually associated with August in Edinburgh, where the International Festival and the bigger, more ragtag Fringe usually promise a cultural hurly-burly. But the pandemic here, as elsewhere, has readjusted realities, as was evident from the moment I arrived last week, primed for a whirlwind weekend of playgoing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bittel
title: Fatal Attraction: Scientists Blame Sea Snake Attacks on Sex Drive
description: Sea snakes aren’t angry when they aggressively swim at divers, scientists say. They’re just confused and looking to mate.
content: If you are ever scuba-diving and a six-foot-long sea snake comes storming out of the shadows, here is what you should know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum, Tiffany Hsu and Katie Robertson
title: How News Organizations Got Afghan Colleagues Out of Kabul
description: The evacuation of those who worked for outlets like The New York Times and The Washington Post came after a global rescue effort stretching from the Pentagon to Qatar.
content: For hours, they waited on the tarmac in the relentless heat, children and suitcases and strollers in tow, hoping for a flight to freedom that would not come. More than 200 Afghans from all walks of life — cooks, gardeners, translators, drivers, journalists — gathered on the runway of the Kabul airport, seeking escape from a country whose government had collapsed with shocking speed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: In Photos: Afghanistan Under the Taliban
description: As the U.S. was winding down its time in the country, the Taliban swiftly retook power, reviving fears of a brutal and violent reign.
content: Twenty years after they were ousted, the Taliban are once again in control of Afghanistan. They swiftly returned to power as the United States was winding down its decades-long presence in the country, where it spent hundreds of billions of dollars to build up the Afghan government and its defense forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Big Tech and the Taliban
description: A wave of pro-Taliban accounts and pages has put social networks in a tricky position.
content: Social media platforms were caught as much by surprise by the Taliban’s takeover of Afghanistan as Western leaders were. Accounts and content linked to the group are rapidly multiplying, as governments around the world decide whether to officially recognize the Taliban as Afghanistan’s rulers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Let Them Taste Cake Again
description: When wedding planning paused, wedding expos died down. Now, all the food-sampling, photographer-shopping and tango-learning is back — in more pandemic-friendly form.
content: The line to enter the Big Fake Wedding New York City expo at City Winery, in Manhattan’s Chelsea neighborhood, moved smoothly and efficiently last month. Brides and grooms, maids of honor, and a handful of mothers were all smiles. Some were masked; others were not. Everyone seemed glad to be there.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Mass Graves, Makeshift Shelters and No Help
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 19, 2021.
content: “When you have a weak state, you feel totally abandoned. It’s like a baby without a mother.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: This Rattlesnake Dares You to Call Its Bluff
description: Scientists designed a virtual reality experiment to understand just how tricky rattlesnakes can be.
content: The Western diamondback rattlesnake is a master of nonverbal communication. It need only shake the rattle on its tail to send a crystal clear message: “Hey. I’m sitting here. Don’t step on me because I’m going to bite you,” said Boris Chagnaud, a biologist at the University of Graz in Austria.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: The T List: Five things we recommend this week
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Can Campus Culture Wars Be Funny? ‘The Chair’ Dares to Think So.
description: Cocreated by Amanda Peet and starring Sandra Oh, the new Netflix series is a sharp satire of academia, touching a number of third rails. Somehow it is also a hilarious rom-com.
content: Spend a bit of time with any progressive teenager, and regardless of your trailblazing bona fides, you might quickly be reduced to a conservative fuddy-duddy. That was the experience the actress and writer Amanda Peet had when her now 14-year-old daughter questioned Peet’s commitment to feminism after she criticized a scantily clad TikToker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: Baryshnikov Arts Center to Continue Online Programming This Fall
description: The digital season will include the premieres of four commissioned pieces and new duets by Kyle Abraham and Liz Gerring.
content: Baryshnikov Arts Center will hold another free online season before welcoming audiences back to its theaters in spring. Mikhail Baryshnikov, who founded the institution in 2005, said the main reason for remaining virtual was a long-planned replacement of its building’s heating, ventilation and air-conditioning system, which is to get underway in fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The Outsider’ Review: Inside the Making of the 9/11 Museum
description: A new documentary focuses on one man involved in the museum’s creation. But it’s not clear why his voice deserved to be heard above others’.
content: Documentaries often cast their subjects in a congratulatory light, but “The Outsider” portrays Michael Shulan, the first creative director of the 9/11 Memorial & Museum, as in effect the last honest historian of Sept. 11, 2001 — a man who wanted to pose “big questions,” per the voice-over, that America might not have been ready to ask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg
title: Hunted by the Taliban, U.S.-Allied Afghan Forces Are in Hiding
description: The Afghan forces disintegrated ahead of the Taliban’s rapid advance. Now, the militants are searching for thousands of Afghan soldiers and security officials.
content: Columns of Afghan soldiers in armored vehicles and pickup trucks sped through the desert to reach Iran. Military pilots flew low and fast to the safety of Uzbekistan’s mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: A California school district will require older students to be vaccinated.
description: Culver City Unified School District is believed to be the first in the state and possibly the nation to require students 12 and older to be inoculated.
content: A small school district in Los Angeles County will require older students to be vaccinated for Covid-19 if they’re eligible, the district’s superintendent said in a letter to families this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: New York’s ‘Excelsior Pass’ could cost up to $27 million.
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration had initially disclosed a $2.5 million cost for development of the app.
content: New York’s digital vaccine app, the Excelsior Pass, will likely cost far more than originally expected, with projected costs nearing $27 million, according to newly obtained documents shared with The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Toyota, hurt by the chip shortage, will reduce output 40 percent in September.
description: The production cut will affect 14 plants in Japan and reduce output by about 140,000 cars and trucks next month, the company said.
content: Toyota Motor, the world’s largest automaker, plans to cut production worldwide 40 percent in September because of a shortage of computer chips that the company had avoided being hurt by until now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: How Our Classrooms Became Battlegrounds
description: Our schools have long been spaces for right-wing extremist panic to  disguise itself as a defense of children.
content: In a way, America’s classrooms have always been auxiliary battlegrounds for the country’s larger culture wars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Sonny Chiba, Japanese Star With a ‘Kill Bill’ Connection, Dies at 82
description: His martial arts movies appalled some with their extreme violence, but the director Quentin Tarantino was a fan and gave him a late-career boost.
content: Sonny Chiba, a Japanese action star who was known for ultraviolent martial arts movies and then, in 2003, was elevated to a whole new level of cinematic trendiness when one of his superfans, the director Quentin Tarantino, gave him a role in “Kill Bill: Vol. 1,” died on Wednesday. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and David Montgomery
title: Fight Over Voting Rights in Texas Nears End as Democrats Return
description: More than 50 Democrats fled to Washington last month to prevent a restrictive voting measure. Three returned to the State Capitol on Thursday, clearing the way for a quorum.
content: HOUSTON — A 38-day walkout by Democrats in the Texas House of Representatives effectively ended on Thursday as three previously absent members arrived in the Capitol, clearing the way for Republicans to establish a quorum and pass restrictive voting rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: A second day of protests against the Taliban.
content: Protesters opposed to the Taliban’s takeover in Afghanistan took to the streets for the second day on Thursday, this time marching in Kabul, including near the presidential palace. content: I was 4 years old when Saigon fell, so I do not remember any of it. I count myself lucky, since many Vietnamese who survived the end of that war were greatly traumatized by it. The collapse of the American-backed Southern regime began in my Central Highlands hometown, Ban Me Thuot, in March 1975. In less than two months, all of South Vietnam capitulated to the North Vietnamese. Soldiers fled in chaotic retreat among civilians. My mother, brother and I were among them. We left behind my adopted sister.
